div.p: S. D. See how generous and liberal I am, my dearest and most esteemed Myconius, I am sending two letters in response to your one. I thank you for your diligent writing; in the previous days, as you see, I wrote earlier, meanwhile, I received nothing from Augsburg except these few lines dated August 6:

"The emperor is in Munich. Before he was ready to depart, the Lord's Supper was held here in the parish of St. George; a large crowd attended, many of them foreigners, especially the English embassy, which is here with 12 horses. The crowd eagerly attends the word of God.
They are not proceeding further than to deliberate on the 9 articles" etc. This and nothing more.
I wish what you report from the account of Mr. Schertli from Leuven and Antwerp were true.
Otherwise, something might break if it happens; for the godless, fierce tyrannical behavior cannot be endured for long.
The plague, unheard of in its cruelty, destroys many in Chur. Many good men have already passed away, among them Mr. Johannes Blasius, the minister; Mr. Johannes Comander has recovered from illness.
I think the matter of WÃ¤denschwyl will now be settled to our advantage in Baden; I will know this thoroughly in 3 or 2 days, and I will let you know as well.

I have shown no hospitality to your son; for today he announces both his departure and his arrival; but you know otherwise how I am disposed towards you and yours. Mr. Vergerius is staying at Mr. Pellicanus's house and is now translating my writings on justification into Italian; he sends you many greetings. Farewell forever.
